name.text: Calculating the Area of Overlapping Circles During Planetary Alignment

questiontext.text:
During a rare planetary alignment, two planets appear as overlapping circular disks when viewed from Earth. Each disk has radius \( {@r@} \,\text{km} \), and the distance between their centres is \( {@d@} \,\text{km} \). The overlapping region is bounded by two circular arcs. At each centre, the chord of intersection subtends an angle of \( {@theta_deg@}^\circ \).

Calculate the area of the overlapping region ,giving your answer in whole numbers.

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to determine the area of the overlapping region of two planetary disks. Each disk has radius r, the distance between their centers is d, and the chord of intersection subtends an angle Î¸ at each center. The solution proceeds as follows:

Step 1: Area of a circular segment

The area of a circular segment is given by:

\( \text{Area of segment} = \text{Area of sector} - \text{Area of triangle} \)

1a. Area of the sector:

\( \begin{align} \text{Area of sector} &= \frac{\theta}{360} \pi r^2 \\ &= \frac{{@theta_deg@}}{360} \times \frac{22}{7} \times {@r@}^2 \\ &= {@sector@}\,\text{km}^2 \end{align} \)

1b. Area of the triangle formed by the chord and radii:

\( \begin{align} \text{Area of triangle} &= \frac{1}{2} r^2 \sin \theta \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \times {@r@}^2 \times \sin({@theta_deg@}^\circ) \\ &= {@triangle@}\,\text{km}^2 \end{align} \)

1c. Area of the segment:

\( \begin{align} \text{Area of segment} &= \text{Area of sector} - \text{Area of triangle} \\ &= {@sector@} - {@triangle@} \\ &= {@seg@}\,\text{km}^2 \end{align} \)

Step 2: Area of overlapping region

Since the overlapping region consists of two identical segments (one from each circle), the total area is:

\( \begin{align} \text{Area of overlap} &= 2 \times \text{Area of segment} \\ &= 2 \times {@seg@} \\ &= {@Overlaping_area@}\,\text{km}^2 \end{align} \)

Rounding to whole numbers:

\( \begin{align} \text{Area of overlapping region} &= {@Area@}\,\text{km}^2 \end{align} \)
